CHAMPPS Videos & Notes

Welcome to the CHAMPPS Videos! These videos serve as a guide/example of each unit activity and the essential elements (universal design for learning strategies, school readiness skill support and lesson extension). For each unit, you will see 1 video with examples of each activity and 1 video with examples of essential elements. We have included a description of each video clip that describes what you should be looking for along with teaching tips.

Unit Example Video

CHAMPPS contains 7 units each focused on a fundamental motor skill (e.g. walking, running, jumping, balance). There are 6 repeated lessons within each unit which includes: Warm-Up, Core 1, Core 2, Core 3, Music Video and Cool Down. We have selected examples from CHAMPPS classrooms that accurately represent how to lead, organize and plan for each unit activity.

Essential Elements of CHAMPPS

CHAMPPS was developed with many UDL strategies that could be used to support the individual needs of children while addressing childrenâ€™s school readiness skills (motor, social, communication, pre-academics, approaches to learning) and physical activity level. To that end, there are many ways that CHAMPPS can be adapted based on the needs of children in the classroom. At the same time, attention should be given to these essential elements of CHAMPPS to ensure that all adaptations to CHAMPPS lessons still meet the core goals of CHAMPPS even when adapted. In essence these essential elements can be used to establish a parameter or boundary for you to know how much can be adapted. You can check off each of the following essential elements after you have made adaptations to the lesson to ensure that your adapted lesson still meets the core or essential elements of CHAMPPS.

Lesson includes:

  • A 30-minute structured lesson that includes: Warm-Up, Core 1, Core 2, Core 3, Music Video and Cool Down.
  • Use of multiple pre-planned strategies to sustain physical activity level and ongoing child engagement such as continuous movement through obstacle courses, child choice, ongoing conversation, prompts and praise as well as use of recommended internal structures (small groups, partners, individual practice),
  • Use of multiple pre-planned UDL strategies to meet individual needs of children in the class.
  • Addresses school readiness skills in 2 or more of the following areas throughout the lesson: motor, communication, social/emotional, pre-academics.

Begin the series

Unit 1: Introductory Skills

CHAMPPS Unit 1 Objectives

Unit Goals

Increase capacity in ….

Lesson Objectives

Child will have multiple opportunities to ……

Motor Movement

Walk, run, stretch, grasp & release, jump, balance & kick

Body Awareness

Identify and use: head, shoulders, waist, arms, legs, knees, hands, feet, heels, toes

Understanding Personal Space

Share space with peers and stay on own floor marker

Motor Imitation

See/imitate movement

Visual Tracking

Throw, watch, catch a scarf

Sustained Physical Activity

Move continuously by imitating motor moves during music video

Sustained Engagement

Use language, make choices, follow directions, a variety of approaches to learning

CHAMPPS Unit 1 Activity Objectives

Activities

Correspondence to Objectives

Warm-Up

· Motor Imitation with scarves

· Elevate Heart Rate

· Warm-Up Muscles

Popcorn Kernels

· Motor Movement: grasp & release

· Body Awareness: catch scarf with 2 hands, 1 hand, knee, foot, elbow

· Visual Tracking: watch and catch scarf

Follow Me Home

· Motor Imitation: look and repeat movement

· Child Choice: pick a new animal & model movement for class

· Personal Space: move about without touching others and return to “home” (floor marker)

· Motor Movement: explore different animal movements

· Language: describe different animals (habitats, food, sound)

· Approaches to Learning: listen for bell and return to floor marker

Simon Says

· Motor Movement

· Body Awareness: identify different body parts

· Motor Imitation: watch and repeat leader

· Follow Directions: listen for Simon Says and repeat movement

· Child Choice: child picks a movement & class follows

· Language Concepts: fast/slow, high/low, up/down, together/apart

Cool Down

· Motor Imitation touch toes, stretch arms, bend and stretch, yoga moves, wave goodbye

· Lower Heart Rate (slow down breathing)

· Cool Down Muscles

Unit 1 Example

 

Unit 1 notes

Time

Description

00:00-00:27

Unit 1: Warm-Up

Note how the teacher

· leads children in singing, jogging until the song ends and carrying/waving scarves

Additional Tip

Children could be prompted to wave scarves high/low or in front/behind their body

00:28 – 00:50

Unit 1: Core Activity 1

Popcorn Kernels

Notehow the teacher

· uses a verbal cue (reach out) while modeling: catching scarf on her arm.

· repeats same verbal cue (reach out) to support children in catching scarf on outstretched arm.

· is attentive to one child, providing proximity support and encouragement

00:51-01:50

Unit 1: Core Activity 2

Follow Me Home

Note how the teacher

· discusses animals using the CHAMPPS visual support cards to describe each animal.

· creates a game with animal pictures by providing clues about animal movement and sound

01:51-02:45

Unit 1: Core Activity 2

Follow Me Home

Note how the teacher

· engages a student by asking him to show the class the visual support card to prepare them for the next animal movement (picture of horse).

· asks open ended questions, how does a horse move?

· shows enthusiasm for the activity

· models galloping and encourages children to imitate, using repeated verbal cue (back-forth, back forth)

· stresses the word gallop as she says it, to reinforce new vocabulary

Note how the teacher employs UDL strategies to encourage participation

· places a child who has difficulty with attention in close proximity

· gives child a leadership role (i.e., He holds the picture card, she touches the card, encourages him to turn it around and show it to the class).

· provides descriptive feedback/praise for participating

Additional Tip

To encourage peer interaction, children could hold hands with a peer and gallop together

02:46-03:16

Unit 1: Core Activity 3

Simon Says

Note how the teacher

· alternates between saying Simon Says and not saying Simon Says, then adds Ms. Bridgett Says

· adds new movements (squat, stand on tiptoes)

· provides intermittent pauses to evaluate how each child is doing.

· praises children who continue squatting as she did not say Ms. Bridgett Says to do the next movement to encourage children to follow directions

· provides verbal feedback to children

Additional Tip

· Choose a few children to be Simon to encourage child choice

03:17-03:39

Unit 1: Core Activity 3

Simon Says

Note how the teacher

· begins by reviewing the rules which encourages active listening.

· is attentive to one child, providing proximity support and encouragement

· models all movements herself and stresses the need to listen for words, Simons Says, before changing movements

· intermittently uses verbal cues (positional words: up/down)

· has the co-teachers distributed among children, moving in close proximity to some who might need more assistance

· has a co-teacher use visual support cards with one child

Additional Tip

Ask a child to lead it or have children take turns leading

03:40-04:11

Unit 1: Music Video

Note how

· all teachers and children are participating

Additional Tip

Provide proximal, praise, prompts to main participation

04:12-05:03

Unit 1: Cool Down

Note how

· the majority of children are participating and all teachers are singing

· teacher uses breathing to encourage cooling down

· teacher is calm for cool down and uses sign language (thank you) at end of CHAMPPS

00:00-00:25

Unit 1: Core Activity 1

UDL: Means of Engagement

Note how the teacher employs UDL strategies to encourage participation

· asks child to choose a body part for catching the scarf

· when child is not heard/understood, asks the child to show everyone the movement

· has children show how they will catch the scarf, after a child suggests catching scarf with one finger

Unit 1 Essential

 

Unit 1 Essential notes

00:26-00:38

Unit 1: Core Activity 1

UDL: Means of Engagement

Note how the teacher employs UDL strategies to encourage participation

· child chooses a body part with which to catch scarf

· child says shoulder and teacher repeats her choice

· teacher models how to catch scarf on your shoulder (places scarf on her shoulder to show children how and where to catch it)

00:39-01:21

Unit 1: Core Activity 3

UDL: Means of Engagement

Note how the teacher employs UDL strategies to encourage participation

· provides child choice & praise

· provides opportunity for children to be leader (Simon)

· assists each child, as needed

· prompts child by saying, “Simon Says…” to encourage participation

01:22-02:28

Unit 1: Core Activity 2

School Readiness: Science

Note how the teacher incorporates school readiness skills

· before starting, children are shown a picture of each animal and asked how each animal moves

· animal movements are modeled by teacher and children practice each move, reinforced with verbal praise.

· children choose when asking questions (i.e., “Is an elephant big or small?” “Does our cheetah go slow or fast?”).

02:29-03:40

Unit 1: Lesson Extension

Cool Down: Animal Safari

Note how the teacher

· reviews animals to foster conversation and imagination

· introduces new vocabulary and movements by suggesting that the path is: bumpy/smooth/ going down a hill fast to encourage all to use their imagination

· children actively participate by talking about animals they imagine seeing

Unit 2: Walking and Running

CHAMPPS Unit 2 Objectives

Unit Goals

Increase capacity in ….

Lesson Objectives

Child will have multiple opportunities to ……

Motor Movement

Walk, speed walk, march, tiptoe, lunch, step over, sidestep, jog, run, stretch

Body Awareness

Identify and move: legs, knees, feet, toes, arms

Understanding Personal Space

Share space with peers and stay on own floor marker

Motor Control

Listen for and initiate: fast vs. slow, stop vs. go

Sustained Physical Activity

Move continuously by imitating motor moves during music video

Sustained Engagement

Use language, make choices, follow directions, a variety of approaches to learning

CHAMPPS Unit 2 Activity Objectives

Activities

Correspondence to Objectives

Warm-Up

· Motor Control with walk vs. jog

· Elevate Heart Rate

· Warm-Up Muscles

Snowflake, Snowflake

· Motor Movement: wave scarf

· Motor Control: listen for movement chosen & initiate

· Personal Space: free movement with awareness of other’s space

· Language: discuss weather

· Approaches to Learning: listen for movement and follow directions

Obstacle Course

· Motor Imitation: watch and repeat movement

· Motor Control: step one foot on each star

· Social Skills: take turns cheering and moving; socialize with peers by cheering friends’ names

Red Light, Green Light

· Motor Control: stop vs. go, slow down

· Motor Imitation: watch and repeat leader

· Follow Directions: listen for Red Light or Green Light and stop or go

· Language Concepts: discuss transportation and traffic rules

Cool Down

· Motor Imitation touch toes, stretch arms, bend and stretch, yoga moves, wave goodbye

· Lower Heart Rate (slow down breathing)

· Cool Down Muscles

Time

Description

00:00-01:08

Unit 2: Core Activity 1

Snowflake, Snowflake

Note how the teacher

· provides child choice

· encourages free movement

· uses a UDL strategy (multiple means of expression) with one child who does not “melt” like other children

01:09-01:34

Unit 2: Core Activity 2

Walk

Note how the teacher

· leads and models for children

· provides verbal reminder walking

01:35-01:50

Unit 2: Core Activity 2

Walk Backwards

Note how

· children cheer for their peers (using shakers)

· teacher creates a challenge: walking backwards

co-teacher simultaneously leads Red Light Green Light with another group of children

01:51-02:15

Unit 2: Core Activity 2

Tiptoe

Note how the teacher

· lowers voice to quietly say tiptoe

· prompts children to tiptoe

02:16-02:31

Unit 2: Core Activity 2

March

Note how the teacher

· leads and models movement

· reminds “leave space for friends”

Additional Tip

For any of these movements, have child lead the group and the teacher could be at the end or in the model to help children who need support.

02:32-03:13

Unit 2: Core Activity 2

Walk

Note how the teacher

· reviews instructions

· matches voice output with speed of movement

· does a practice first and participates alongside the children

03:14-03:41

Unit 2: Core Activity 2

Sidestep

Note how the teacher

· stands in front and uses red and green stars as visual supports to signal stop/go

· pauses to monitor participation and following directions

03:42-06:04

Unit 2: Music Video

Cruisin’ Down the Freeway

Note how the teacher

· ensures personal space with children standing with outstretched arms

· provides verbal prompts and encouragement

· utilizes all staff members and encourages movement/participation; prompts teaching assistant to help children when needed

· models for those who experience difficulty (i.e., notice child who looks at peers for help); holds hands with children to engage them at their level

· children moving continuously to music video

Additional Tip

Teacher stands in front of children to serve as another model

06:05-06:42

Unit 2: Cool Down

Bend & Stretch

Note how the teacher

· models and provides clear verbal instruction

· provides individual support for participation and her colleagues are interspersed between children

Unit 2 Essential

 

Unit 2 Essential notes

00:00-00:42

Unit 2: School Readiness

Language: Transition

Note how the teacher incorporates school readiness skills

· reviews instructions for Red Light Green Light and Obstacle Course

· asks questions about what to do in each activity

· provides an opportunity for children to respond

00:43-01:15

Unit 2: School Readiness

Literacy: Letter Recognition

Note how the teacher incorporates school readiness skills

· expands lesson following a student comment

· sounds out the letter H

· provides examples of words that start with H

· uses Letter of the Week to choose next movement (hop)

Additional Tip

This unit focuses on Walking & Running. Ideally, you would incorporate movements that focus on the unit objectives (i.e., walking with Hands swinging at side; running while clapping Hands). However, this is an excellent example of a teacher adapting a lesson based on student interest and integrates other content from curriculum into CHAMPPS.

01:16-01:54

Unit 2: School Readiness

Math: Number Recognition

Note how the teacher incorporates school readiness skills

· asks children to identify their numbers (on floor marker) before putting scarves away. This strategy intentionally incorporates school readiness skill into transition.

Additional Tip

Have children say the number on their marker, and have those with matching numbers put a scarf away

01:55-02:12

Unit 2: School Readiness

Science: Living Things

Note how the teacher incorporates school readiness skills

· follows child’s lead, creating a learning opportunity after a child comments about being cold

· describes moving fast to warm up bodies

Additional Tip

Could incorporate more questions to expand on language and critical thinking skills (i.e., What are wayswe can warm-up our bodies? Why does our body get warm when we move?)

02:13-03:13

Unit 2: School Readiness

Science: Living Things

Note how the teacher incorporates school readiness skills

· children place hands on chest to feel their heartbeat and use language to describe their heartbeat 

· asks why they think hearts are beating slower, encouraging critical thinking and use of language

· provides clues/prompts (i.e., Is stretching a fast activity or slow activity?)

· uses UDL strategy: sign language for thank you, all done

Additional Tip

Remind children what side their heart is on, for some children had their hand on the left side and some had it on the right side

03:14-03:31

Unit 2: UDL: Means of Representation

Multiple Levels of Complexity

Note how the teacher employs UDL strategies to encourage participation

· provides clear directions for the activity

· reviews rules/reminders to ensure clear expectations

· reinforces rules at end with praise for following directions (named specific children)

Additional Tip

All adults could sing song and children can be encouraged to join in the singing too

03:32-04:20

Unit 2: UDL: Means of Representation

Multiple Levels of Complexity

Note how the teacher employs UDL strategies to encourage participation

· provides clear instructions (verbal as well as gestural); boys go through first while girls cheer.

· leads the line and models tiptoe

04:21-04:40

Unit 2: UDL: Means of Representation

Multiple Forms of Communication

Note how the teacher employs UDL strategies to encourage participation

· models movement

· uses visual representation for green light and red light

04:41-04:54

Unit 2: UDL: Means of Expression

Vary Response Options

Note how the teacher employs UDL strategies to encourage participation

· when child has difficulty with verbal expression, the teachers prompts her to show the movement, rather than use words

04:55-05:36

Unit 2: Lesson Extension

Warm-Up Stretch

Note how

· each child has 2 scarves

· children have the opportunity to manipulate the scarves

· the teacher leads with an opening stretch with the scarves before singing Warm-Up song

· the teacher provides descriptive feedback about the child (“Nice job Carter, you did it.”)

05:37-06:49

Unit 2: Lesson Extension

Cool Down: Yoga

Not how the teacher

· models each movement slowly

· provides verbal prompts/instruction

provides opportunity for quiet time (no singing)

06:50-07:18

Unit 2: Lesson Extension

Cool Down: Rest

Lesson Extension: Rest

· provides individual support for a child to rest next to her

· class remains quiet during rest time

· slowly prompts children to wiggle toes, knees, fingers, sit up

07:19-07:43

Unit 2: Lesson Extension

Cool Down: Breathing

Lesson Extension: Deep Breathing

· extends the cool down to include deep breathing

· includes cool down song but slows it down and pauses for deep breathes

· use hand movements to help children take deep breathes

Unit 3: Balance, Jumping and Hopping

CHAMPPS Unit 3 Objectives

Unit Goals

Increase capacity in ….

Lesson Objectives

Child will have multiple opportunities to ……

Motor Movement

Balance, jump, gallop, skip, hop, leap, sway, jog, stretch

Body Awareness

Identify and move: feet, legs, knees, arms

Dynamic Balance

Move and balance.Walk on balance beam, step/hop onto floor markers

Static Balance

Maintain balance while standing in one spot

Motor Planning

Think about and plan movement through obstacle course

Sustained Physical Activity

Move continuously by imitating motor moves during music video

Sustained Engagement

Use language, make choices, follow directions, a variety of approaches to learning

CHAMPPS Unit 3 Activity Objectives

Activities

Correspondence to Objectives

Warm-Up

· Motor Imitation

· Elevate Heart Rate

· Warm-Up Muscles

Rabbits and Foxes

· Motor Movement: focus on jumping and balancing

· Body Awareness: control speed and body movement

· Personal Space: move about without touching others and return to “home” (floor marker)

· Science: ask questions about animals (habitats, movements, sounds)

· Approaches to Learning: listen for bell and return to floor marker

Hungry Horsey

· Motor Movement: focus on dynamic balance and encourage holding with 1 hand only

· Personal Space: move about without touching others and return to “home” (floor marker)

· Language: describe horses (habitat, food)

River Jump

· Motor Movement: focus on balance and leaping

· Social Skills: take turns cheering and moving

· Approaches to Learning: stay on task during small group

· Science: describe animals (movements, habitats, food)

Cool Down

· Motor Imitation touch toes, stretch legs, bend and stretch, yoga moves, wave goodbye

· Lower Heart Rate (slow down breathing)

· Cool Down Muscles

Unit 3 Activities

 

Unit 3 Activities notes

Time

Description

00:00-00:43

Unit 3: Warm-Up

Balance

Notice how the teacher

· uses open-ended question (i.e., What do we do first?) to support language, familiarity and predictability with the CHAMPPS routine

· models the balance movement

· includes numeracy (i.e., count to 5)

· all staff are involved

00:44-01:17

Unit 3: Warm-Up

Galloping

Notice how the teacher

· starts with discussion on animals (i.e., What does a horsey do?)

· keeps children moving continuously to sustain physical activity

Additional Tip

If some children do not know how to gallop, take time before the warm-up to model a gallop and provide verbal prompts (i.e., one foot forward, rock backwards, rock forwards).

01:18-01:30

Unit 3: Warm-Up

Skipping

Notice how the teacher

· keeps children moving continuously to sustain physical activity

Additional Tip

If some children do not know how to skip, take time before the warm-up to model a skip, providing verbal prompts (i.e., first step, then hop); peers also can serve as models

01:31-02:00

Unit 3: Core Activity 1

Jumping Bunnies

Notice how the teacher

· reviews instructions and reinforces active listening (i.e., What do you do when you hear Look Out Fox?)

· has children sing along

· and her colleagues are all participating

· allows free movement to encourage continuous movement

· jumps along the edge of the carpet to serve as a model and observe children in the middle

02:01-03:04

Unit 3: Core Activity 2

Hungry Horsey

Notice how the teacher

· has children move continuously through the activity to minimize wait-time and maximize physical activity

· uses proximity to support children, walking alongside them if individualized assistance is needed

· reinforces using two hands to hold the noodle to balance the apple

· remains aware, noticing when a child has difficulty using the tall noodle

· Provides child choice by allowing her to use the tall noodle once, then has her switch to a smaller noodle

Additional Tip

Using a taller noodle provides an additional challenge but if it is too tall, the child will not be successful. In addition, when the noodle is too tall, it is difficult to gallop in the end. Therefore, the noodles should not be taller than the height of child.

03:05-03:49

Unit 3: Core Activity 2

Hungry Horsey

Notice how the teacher

· Has children move in a continuous loop to minimize wait-time and maximize physical activity

· provides prompting to child who needs it

· stands close by to provide individualized assistance, as needed

Additional Tip

This is an excellent activity for reinforcing grasp/release and visual tracking. If an apple falls down, point to it, to help the child visually track it; prompt him/her to pick it up and put it back on the noodle.

03:50-04:39

Unit 3: Core Activity 2

Hungry Horsey

Notice how the teacher

· provides specific praise (i.e., I like how he steps on each stone.)

· varies the level of challenge by encouraging children to hold the noodle with 1 or 2 hands, depending on their ability

Notice how the children

· step on one stone at a time and then carefully walk across the balance beams

· step over each hurdle, then drop the apple into the bucket and gallop back to repeat the obstacle course with more/less apples and same/different size and color noodle.

Additional Tip

· To decrease wait time, have more than one child do through the obstacle course at a time

04:40-05:12

Unit 3: Core Activity 3

River Jump

Notice how the teacher

· has half the small group cheering with egg shakers while the other half moves through the course

· encourages cheering and movement (i.e., quacks behind child)

· provides verbal and nonverbal (thumbs up) feedback

Additional Tip

· encourage social interaction and language by having children use the names of their peers when cheering (i.e. Go Jill Go!) or create a cheer!

· observe how children move through the course and provide feedback (i.e., Are the children moving around each cone and following the star path? Are they waddling?)

05:13-05:43

Unit 3: Core Activity 3

River Jump

Notice how the teacher

· models placing the bean bags under your arms

· models walking on the path following the stars and leaping on floor markers at the end; also she verbally describes what she is doing

05:44-06:11

Unit 3: Music Video

Cool Sports

Notice how the teacher

· positions adults throughout the room to serve a multiple models for children

· does not restrict movement. Children move (hop) all over carpet.

06:12-06:23

Unit 3: Music Video

Jump

Notice how the teacher

· provides 1-on-1 support to a child, as needed

· provides 1-on-1 support for another child by holding hands to encourage participation

Notice how the children

· can be heard singing along to the music video

are attentive to the music video and engaged in active listening to follow the movements of the video

06:24-07:31

Unit 3: Music Video

Jump

Notice how the teacher

· provides prompting and encouragement for children; she calls out specific children by name to encourage movement

· sustains children’s physical activity level

07:32-08:27

Unit 3: Music Video

Jump

Notice how the teacher

· positions adults throughout the room to serve as multiple models for children

· stands in close proximity to a child who needs prompting

Notice how the children

· have free movement

· are laughing with others

· interact over a shared activity and encourage each other, as one child tells another to jump higher!

08:28-08:49

Unit 3: Cool Down

Touch Toes

Notice how the teacher

· allows child choice regarding where to sit, not restricted to the floor markers

· includes body awareness and asks, Where are your toes?

Additional Tip

· ask a child to lead the song

choose a different child to lead each warm-up movement

08:50-09:27

Unit 3: Cool Down

Bend and Stretch

Notice how the teacher

· models and provides clear description of the movements (i.e., one hand on the floor and one hand way up high)

· and her colleagues are all participating and therefore serving as models of the activities

Additional Tip

· before sitting, have children use outstretched arms to ensure they have enough personal space (i.e., are not touching a friend while stretching)

09:28-09:53

Unit 3: Cool Down

Stretch Arms

Notice how the teacher

· models and provides clear instructions for how to stretch arms

· when switching arms, slides one hand down and the other up which provides a clear visual representation of the right vs left arm/hand

09:54-10:05

Unit 3: Cool Down

Wave Goodbye

Notice how the teacher

· positions children, sitting in a circle facing one another so all serve as models for one another

Notice how the children

· join in the song and movements

Unit 3 Essential

 

Unit 3 Essential notes

00:00-00:13

Unit 3: UDL: Means of Representation

Multiple Means of Complexity

Note how the teacher

· observes a child experiencing uncertainty, pauses the activity to model the movement, says, Look at Ms. Toni and then, describes the movement saying, You have to move your body.

Additional Tip

· have a peer model how to waddle

00:14-00:30

Unit 3: UDL: Means of Engagement

Sustain Interest

Note how the teacher

· provides child choice, asking child to choose the next movement

· follows child’s lead with the idea to fly and hop simultaneously, not limiting the child to choose only one movement.

· adds a challenge by using two movement at a time

· allows child to model flying and hopping for peers

00:31-01:06

Unit 3: UDL: Means of Engagement

Sustain Interest

Note how the teacher

· describes how to make the activity easier (hold noodle at top) or more challenging (hold noodle at bottom)

· provides opportunity for the children to choose where to hold the noodle

· encourages children to cheer and use 2 fingers as to not distract the other small group

01:07-01:26

Unit 3: UDL: Means of Engagement

Sustain Interest

Note how

· the teacher ensures that the activity is within the ability level of each child

· the children balance bean bags under arms and on head and then the teacher simplifies the activity (balance on hand instead of head) when one child drops one of the bean bags

01:27-02:45

Unit 3: UDL: Means of Engagement

Organize for Engagement

Note how the teacher

· remains attentive to children who are not participating, circulates around the room

· provides one child the option to sit down when not responding to prompts (commenting that the child might not be feeling well)

· holds hands with a child who appears distracted, standing nearby to offer individualize support

· models movement for child

· slows down pace of movement and focuses on one movement at a time

· continues to ask questions in order to understand the level of support the child requires (i.e., Do you want me to hold your hand? Do you want me to pick you up?)

· provides descriptive feedback when child jumps

· multiple teachers provides support to other children who are experiencing difficulty

02:46-03:06

Unit 3: UDL: Means of Engagement

Vary Complexity

Note how the teacher

· quickly jumps in to provide assistance

· suggests an alternative way to hold noodle

· allows children the opportunity to add more “apples” to balance, which provides more challenge

03:07-03:36

Unit 3: UDL: Means of Expression

Vary Response Format

Note how the teacher

· communicates with other teacher about allowing a child to choose to lay down and rest if needed

· offers an alternative way to participate in music video as the teachers tells child “it’s ok, we can pretend to sleep right here” when he does not respond to lay down prompt

· stands with child to sway side to side instead of laying down

03:37-03:47

Unit 3: UDL: Means of Expression

Vary Response Format

Note how the teacher

· encourages language with open-ended question such as What was your favorite part about CHAMPPS?

· accepts multiple types of responses such as a child who has difficulty with verbal communication, he points to favorite activity and the teacher provides the verbal response saying, Oh, the music video!

03:48-04:13

Unit 3: School Readiness

Engage in Active Discussion

Note how the teacher

· asks open-ended questions about the activity

· provides specific instructions for the activity

· models movement while reinforcing language by asking And what’s that called?

04:14-04:24

Unit 3: School Readiness

Engage in Active Discussion

Note how the teacher

· encourages use of language and asks “where are you putting them?”

· reinforces new vocabulary (i.e., under arms)

Additional Tip

· You could expand vocabulary (“Yes, you put the pink one under your arm.”) and knowledge of positional words by asking the child, What is the opposite of under? What is opposite of high/low? Up/down?

04:25-04:41

Unit 3: School Readiness

Picture Recognition

Note how the teacher

· switches to use small beans bags with photos on them (vocabulary) for an added challenge

· asks child to identify the picture on each bean bag

Additional Tip

· You could add more language by asking questions about the picture on beanbags such as How do bunnies move? What is an igloo made of? Where would we find an igloo? How does a horse move? Where do horses live? What do horses eat? What sound do horses make?

04:42-04:58

Unit 3: School Readiness

Engage in Active Discussion

Note how the teacher

· uses the break time between music videos to focus on asking one child about movements used during skiing.

04:59-05:44

Unit 3: School Readiness

Express Personal Interests

Note how the teacher

· provides a language opportunity when children are asked to describe their favorite activity

· expands on a child’s comment about a favorite activity by asking the rest of the class, How many apples did you balance? This opens up the discussion to the whole call, keeps children engaged in the conversation while also giving each individual child a language opportunity.

05:45-06:11

Unit 3: School Readiness

Formal and Informal Language

Note how the teacher

· incorporates language by asking children to help her remember the song

· integrates content from classroom curriculum (letter of the week) within CHAMPPS activity

· children start to sing the song before the activity

06:12-06:38

Unit 3: School Readiness

Names

Note how the teacher

· encourages children to the names of adults and peers

· elaborates on comment (i.e., she is the fox) and asks follow-up questions

06:39-06:56

Unit 3: School Readiness

Turn Taking

Note how the teacher

· prompts turn-taking

· Children engage with one another when switching roles between cheering and doing the obstacle course

06:57-07:20

Unit 3: School Readiness

Counting

Note how the teacher

· Leads a math conversation about dividing the class in half for small groups; We need to figure out how to split our group!

· Children volunteer answers to What is half of 8?

· Provides visual representation of the numbers (using hands) and repeats child’s response

· provides praise saying, You could be the teacher! You are awesome.

07:21-08:08

Unit 3: Lesson Extension

Warm-Up

Note how the teacher

· extends the balance movement in warm-up

· creates a challenge by “holding your foot” while balancing

· follows child’s lead to count to 6 instead of 5

· adds more challenge by prompting children to close their eyes while balancing

08:09-08:32

Jumping Bunnies

Note how the teacher

· prompts child to recall a story read in the classroom

· integrates the story into “Rabbit & Foxes” activity

08:33-08:44

Unit 3: Lesson Extension

River Jump

Note how the teacher

· creates a “wait-time” activity

· during “wait time” children balance beanbags on head, providing another opportunity to reinforce balance

Unit 4: Catching

CHAMPPS Unit 4 Objectives

Unit Goals

Increase capacity in ….

Lesson Objectives

Child will have multiple opportunities to ……

Motor Movement

Roll arms, jumping jacks, roll, throw, pass, catch, hold, kneel

Body Awareness

Identify and use: hands, arms, fingers, eyes, elbows, knees

Hand-Eye Coordination

Watch ball. Eyes guide hands to catch.

Visual Tracking

Watch & catch ball

Grasp & Release

Catch, hold, let go and pass/roll/throw ball

Sustained Physical Activity

Move continuously by imitating motor moves during music video

Sustained Engagement

Use language, make choices, follow directions, a variety of approaches to learning

CHAMPPS Unit 4 Activity Objectives

Activities

Correspondence to Objectives

Warm-Up

· Motor Imitation

· Elevate Heart Rate

· Warm-Up Muscles

Pass the Ball

· Motor Movement: focus on balance, passing and catching; grasp & release

· Social Skills: wait-turn and work together to keep balls moving

Roll & Catch

· Motor Movement: focus on grasp and release

· Math: encourage number recognition and ask children to find their number

· Social Skills: participate in cooperative play with a partner, independent of adults

· Approaches to Learning: listen for bell and children switch from sitting to kneeling

Throw & Catch

· Motor Movement: focus on grasp and release

· Math: encourage number recognition and ask children to find their number

· Social Skills: participate in cooperative play with a partner, independent of adults

· Approaches to Learning: listen for bell and children switch from kneeling to standing

Cool Down

· Motor Imitation stretch arms, roll arms, bend and stretch, play piano/drums, yoga moves, wave goodbye

· Lower Heart Rate (slow down breathing)

· Cool Down Muscles

Unit 5: Throwing

CHAMPPS Unit 5 Objectives

Unit Goals

Increase capacity in ….

Lesson Objectives

Child will have multiple opportunities to ……

Motor Movement

Throw, swim, watch, hold, roll arms

Body Awareness

Identify and use: hands, arms, elbows, fingers, eyes, feet, knees

Hand-Eye Coordination

Watch ball. Eyes guide hands to throw and catch.

Visual Tracking

Watch & catch ball.

Force

Throw ball hard vs. soft to reach target.

Sustained Physical Activity

Move continuously by imitating motor moves during music video

Sustained Engagement

Use language, make choices, follow directions, a variety of approaches to learning

CHAMPPS Unit 5 Activity Objectives

Activities

Correspondence to Objectives

Warm-Up

· Motor Imitation

· Elevate Heart Rate

· Warm-Up Muscles

Snowballs in the Air

· Motor Movement: focus on underhand vs. overhand throw

· Body Awareness: catch bean bag with 2 hands

· Visual Tracking: watch and catch bean bag

Snowman Throw

· Motor Movement: focus on overhand throw; grasp & release

· Science: discuss force (throw hard vs. soft)

· Language Concepts: pick letter or shape target for children

· Approaches to Learning: follow directions, remain focused, exhibit independence

Bottle Bowling

· Motor Movement: focus on underhand throw; grasp & release

· Science: discuss force

· Approaches to Learning: remain focused, exhibit independence

Cool Down

· Motor Imitation touch toes, stretch arms, bend and stretch, yoga moves, wave goodbye

· Lower Heart Rate (slow down breathing)

· Cool Down Muscles

Unit 5 Example

 

Unit 5 Example notes

Time

Description

00:00-00:32

Unit 5: Warm-Up

Roll Arms

Notice how the teacher

· adds a challenge with dual movement (roll arms and walk)

· supports school readiness skills by defining positional words (what is the opposite of forward)

Additional Tip

· Encourage children to sing along as it reinforces language and engagement.

· Space adults between children so they can serve as models 

00:33-01:35

Unit 5: Warm-Up

Swim & March

Notice how the teacher

· begins the warm-up with swimming and gradually adds marching

· distributes other adults among children so as to provide additional support

· incorporates positional words (forward and backward)

· compliments one child after that child has praised another child

01:36-02:08

Unit 5: Warm-Up

Jumping Jacks

Notice how the teacher

· uses verbal prompts to describe movement (I and X)

· supports language and literacy skills by using letters to describe movement (I and X)

· models/describes the movement

· chooses counting (jumping jacks) instead of singing, to draw attention to a new and more complex movement

Additional Tip

· Encourage children to do a quick check of personal space with outstretched arms to ensure that all have enough space to successfully complete jumping jacks.

02:09-03:22

Unit 5: Core Activity 1

Snowballs in the Air

Notice how the teacher

· stands in close proximity to children who need prompting

· provides individualized prompts to children who are not participating

· encourages children to sing along

· provides clear instruction (one bean bag then hop back, hand to hand)

03:23-05:04

Unit 5: Core Activity 1

Snowballs in the Air

Notice how the teacher

· asks children to join in singing before the start of the activity

· increases child engagement by modeling different ways of throwing (high, low, side-to-side)

· provides child choice by allowing children to move outside of their floor marker

· uses the floor marker as a way to re-group and change instructions (i.e., move from high throw to low throw)

· provides specific instructions for underhand throw

05:05-05:28

Unit 5: Core Activity 2

Snowman Throw

Notice how

· the activities (Snowman Throw and Bottle Bowling) occur simultaneously

· each child has own station, providing multiple opportunities for overhand throw (Snowman Throw) and underhand throw (Bottle Bowling)

· snowman stations are numbered and have pictures integrated into snowman while bottle bowling stations are lettered – both supporting language

05:29-06:20

Unit 5: Core Activity 2

Snowman Throw

Notice how the teacher

· waits until all children are ready

· provides specific instruction (Pick up 1 bean bag and hit the blue circle 3 times.), which supports listening to multi-step directions and counting

· allows children to do independent practice while providing individual assistance to children as needed

· poses questions (What animal are you hitting?) which supports science and language

· recruits others to lead another small group (Bottle Bowling)

06:21-07:50

Unit 5: Core Activity 3

Botte Bowling

Notice how the teacher

· stays with same group of children to observe and provide prompts

· adapts the activity to meet the ability level of each child by increasing or decreasing the number of bottles (i.e. one children has only one bottle)

· pauses activity to re-group and counts to 3 before rolling

· places each child at a bowling station with assigned letter (B, C, D)

· encourages each child to independently reset bottles

07:51-08:47

Unit 5: Core Activity 3

Botte Bowling

Notice how the teacher

· ensures all children are prepared and ready to start the activity

· gestures underhand throw before starting the activity

· ensures that all children have their own station

· encourages each child to independently reset bottles

· encourages all children to retrieve their own balls

· provides individualized support to children, when needed

08:48-09:05

Unit 5: Core Activity 3

Botte Bowling

Notice how the teacher

· encourages children to independently reset bottles

· encourages use of 2 hands to throw the ball

Additional Tip

· Encourage children to start throwing with 2 hands then, add a challenge by asking the child to throw with only 1 hand.

Wave Goodbye

· Increase chance for success by allowing child to take a few steps forward before throwing beanbag. This creates a shorter distance for throwing.

Unit 6: Striking

CHAMPPS Unit 6 Objectives

Unit Goals

Increase capacity in ….

Lesson Objectives

Child will have multiple opportunities to ……

Motor Movement

Twist, lunge, swing, tap

Body Awareness

Identify and use: stomach, arms, legs, knees, eyes, hands

Hand-Eye Coordination

Watch ball. Eyes guide hands to strike.

Visual Tracking

Watch & strike balloon/ball

Force

Strike hard vs. soft.

Sustained Physical Activity

Move continuously by imitating motor moves during music video

Sustained Engagement

Use language, make choices, follow directions, a variety of approaches to learning

CHAMPPS Unit 6 Activity Objectives

Activities

Correspondence to Objectives

Warm-Up

· Motor Imitation

· Elevate Heart Rate

· Warm-Up Muscles

Balloons in the Sky

· Motor Movement: focus on striking a moving object

· Hand-Eye Coordination: watch ball, eyes guide hands to strike

· Visual Tracking: toss and catch balloon with 2 hands

Tee-Ball

· Motor Movement: focus on striking a stationary object

· Hand-Eye Coordination: watch ball, eyes guide hands to strike

· Approaches to Learning: work independently and set up own station

Hockey

· Motor Movement: focus on striking

· Hand-Eye Coordination: watch ball, eyes guide hands to strike

· Approaches to Learning: work independently and set up own station

· Language Concepts: listen for verbal prompts

Cool Down

· Motor Imitation stretch arms, roll arms, play piano, yoga moves, wave goodbye

· Lower Heart Rate (slow down breathing)

· Cool Down Muscles

Unit 6 Example

 

Unit 6 Example notes

Time

Description

00:00-01:04

Unit 6: Warm-Up

Roll Arms & March

Notice how teacher

· models and describes movements

· supports language by emphasizing positional words (forward and backward)

Uses UDL strategies such as

· engage children by adding dual movement (marching and rolling arms)

· alternate between quiet and loud activities (stomping)

· fluctuate tone of voice to match movement

· children stay in their own space but engage in continuous movement (marching in place versus moving around the carpet marching)

· child choice: some children roll arms with straight arms while others keep their arms bent and close to their bodies

01:05-01:29

Unit 6: Warm-Up

Jumping Jacks

Notice how teacher

· encourages children to join in singing

· models movement; one teacher models a jumping jack while another teacher models a modified jumping jack (bends knees and claps hands)

Uses UDL strategies such as

· changes pace to keep children engaged

· accepts partial movement where one child stands and claps his hands instead of doing a complete jumping jack

Additional Tip

· provide verbal prompts for children who may not know how to do a jumping jack

01:30-02:04

Unit 6: Warm-Up

Twist

Notice how the teacher

· provides continuous prompts to encourage participation and singing

· engages all children in singing while using a quiet voice to allow them to take the lead

Uses UDL strategies

· accepts participation with partial movement (hands at sides with slight twist at waist)

02:05-02:54

Unit 6: Warm-Up

Lunge

Notice how the teacher

· uses the floor marker as a reference point when lunging with alternate legs

· extends the warm-up lunges with a review, asking the children to lunge a couple more times without the song so as to observe the ability level of each child.

Uses UDL strategy

· stands in close proximity to a child who participates with partial movement (small steps and slight bend in knee rather than a complete lunge)

02:55-04:32

Unit 6: Core Activity 1

Balloons in the Air

Notice how teacher

· instructs children to retrieve their own balloons using the numbers on their floor markers

· models and provides clear instruction at the start of the activity

· observes and prompts children who are not following her instructions

· show and verbally prompts children that they can squeeze their balloons to catch them and not to be afraid, they won’t pop

· begins the activity with a simple movement (throw balloons gently and catch with 2 hands)

· supports language by asking children how their balloon throw went 

Uses UDL strategy

· matches tone of voice to movement (start with low, quiet voice in the beginning for gentle movement)

· gradually speeds up pace once children master the previous movement (how did you do?do you want to go higher?)

· uses balloons of various sizes and colors

04:33-05:48

Unit 6: Core Activity 1

Balloons in the Air

Notice how teacher

· begins the activity with a simple movement (toss and catch) and then progresses to more challenging movements (tap the balloon in the air, tap the balloon side to side between hands)

· focuses on tapping the balloon, rather than toss and catch, in order to reinforce the unit objective (striking)

· leads an additional round of the activity and encourages singing

05:49-05:54

Unit 6: Core Activity 2

Tee-Ball

Notice how the teacher

· has adults provide assistance when needed while children do the activity independently

· sets the T-Ball stations at different heights to better match the height of the child

· numbers each T-Ball station so children are encouraged to use the number as a target

05:55-06:22

Unit 6: Core Activity 2

Tee-Ball

Notice how the teacher

· encourages children to stand with 1 foot on each floor marker and swing with 2 hands

· circulates to each child to provide assistance where needed while children complete activity independently

06:23-07:56

Unit 6: Core Activity 3

Hockey

Notice how the teacher

· places children into 2 small groups with adults running the two activities simultaneously

· adjusts the station for children who are left- and right-handed; tells other teacher why child would approach task differently if left-handed

· provides clear instructions and observes that each child is completing the movement correct (both feet on floor markers, 2 hands)

provides continuous prompts as children complete the activity independently

07:57-08:56

Unit 6: Core Activity 3

Hockey

Notice how the children

· are positioned at their own hockey station

· use 1 hand or 2 hands, depending on child preference/level

· resets their bottles

· positions the ball between 2 orange stars to keep it in place

08:57-10:30

Unit 6: Music Video

Roomba Dance

· instructs children to check their personal space with outstretched arms before starting video

· encourages free movement

· provides prompts (jog in place, happy face)

· provides descriptive feedback (I like how you all froze, that’s good body control)

· responds to children’s comments

10:31-13:10

Unit 6: Cool Down

Notice how the teacher

· provides clear instruction and models each movement

· provides sentence starters to encourage language (next we are going to _______)

encourages children to sing

00:00-00:42

Wake Up Bodies

Notice how the teacher

· begins by adding some stretches

· supports language by asking children to say good morning and echo her words

00:43-02:19

Lesson Extension: Balloons in the Air

Balloon Wiggle

Notice how the teacher

· reinforces knowledge of positional words (up, down)

· reinforces motor skills by asking children to hop to put their balloons away

· supports language by asking children to identify the color of their balloons

Additional Tip

· reinforce additional positional words by saying, wiggle the balloon side to side, behind your back, in front of your tummy, next to your ear

· sustain engagement and reinforce color recognition by choosing a new movement for each color; white balloon jog, yellow balloon skip, blue balloons lunge

02:20-03:09

Lesson Extension: Cool Down

Breathing

Notice how the teacher

· smoothly and quietly transitions into cool down activity by adding deep breathing while children are lying down at the end of music video

03:10-04:10

School Readiness: Math

Number Recognition

Notice how the teacher

· ask children to identify the number on their floor marker

· ensures that each child knows their number

· creates a smooth transition by calling a few numbers at a time

· asks children about number sequence (What comes after 0?)

· provides a visual prompt by holding up fingers

04:11-04:48

School Readiness: Math

Number Recognition

Notice how the teacher

· children identify the number on their floor marker before getting a balloon

· emphasizes Q words (quick and quiet, our Q words)

· allows children to engage in conversation with one another as they wait

04:49-05:31

School Readiness: Language

Engage in Active Discussion

Notice how the teacher

· asks children to describe their thoughts/feelings about the activity (what was easiest/hardest) and then repeats the child’s response

Additional Tip

· ask follow-up questions (Why was it easier or harder?)

05:32-07:13

School Readiness: Language

Engage in Active Discussion

Notice how the teacher

· asks each child to describe his/her favorite activities

· encourages children to use their words and use complete sentences

Additional Tip

· provide specific feedback in response to each child (i.e. yes the balloons were fun to toss and catch or right, I saw you lunging during the video)

07:14-07:50

School Readiness: Language

Colors

Notice how the teacher

· has each child identify the color of his/her balloon

· provides prompts and reminds children of instructions (What color do you have? I am only doing red)

Uses UDL strategy

· utilizes all adults to help provide individualized assistance to children as needed

· provides descriptive feedback (Good listening, I like how you know your colors!)

07:51-11:11

School Readiness: Language

Listen/Use Formal and Informal Language

Notice how the teacher

· asks question at the start of each movement

· has children sing along with movement

· asks questions about letters (L, S, R, J) 

· provides support for sounding out the letters (J - Jumping Jack!)

11:12-11:53

School Readiness: Social

Independence/Self Help

Notice how the teacher

· uses bell to signal transition/reset station

· instructs children to reset station for their friends

· has children wait for peers to finish reset before transition

11:54-12:25

School Readiness: Social

Peer Interaction

Notice how the teacher

· children engage in conversation with one another during shared activity (i.e., One girl says to another: “Do like me.”

12:26-13:22

UDL: Means of Representation

Multiple Levels of Complexity

Notice how the teacher

· provides specific instructions about how to complete each activity

· models swinging movement and children imitate

· supports language by asking questions

· uses vocabulary that may be new to some children (pendulum, sideways, racket)

13:23-13:56

UDL: Means of Representation

Multiple Communication Forms

Notice how the teacher

· provides verbal prompts (2 hands, pendulum swing)

provides model and different levels of support (i.e., hand over hand support)

13:57-14:28

UDL: Means of Engagement

Alternate Active vs. Quiet Activities

Notice how the teacher

· uses a “speed round” of balloons in the air to engage children in the activity

· allows children have free movement

· asks questions to review the concept of control

14:29-15:19

UDL: Means of Engagement

Organize for Engagement

Notice how the teacher

· circulates between small groups

· distributes adults across small groups

all adults to provide varied levels of support as needed (1 on 1 support vs whole group support)

15:20-15:56

UDL: Means of Engagement

Organize for Engagement

Notice how the teacher

· adjusts the height of T-ball by adding or removing blocks to better match child’s height

15:57-16:19

UDL: Means of Expression

Multiple Ways of Expression and/or Response Formats

Notice how the teacher

· gives attention to how each station is set up to ensure the successful participation of each child

· switches floor markers to match the needs of each child (left versus right handed)

Unit 7: Kicking

CHAMPPS Unit 7 Objectives

Unit Goals

Increase capacity in ….

Lesson Objectives

Child will have multiple opportunities to ……

Motor Movement

Kick, trap, dribble, ride bike, tap

Body Awareness

Identify and use: feet, toes, knees

Visual Tracking

Watch and trap ball

Force

Throw ball hard vs. soft to reach target

Accuracy

Kick ball in direction of target

Sustained Physical Activity

Move continuously by imitating motor moves during music video

Sustained Engagement

Use language, make choices, follow directions, a variety of approaches to learning

CHAMPPS Unit 7 Activity Objectives

Activities

Correspondence to Objectives

Warm-Up

· Motor Imitation

· Elevate Heart Rate

· Warm-Up Muscles

We Tap the Ball

· Motor Movement: emphasize controlled movement (trapping the ball)

· Visual Tracking: watch and trap ball

· Math: support number recognition

· Approaches to Learning: use a bell to support an easy transition between movements

Roll & Kick

· Motor Movement: focus on kicking for distance and controlling force

· Visual Tracking: watch and trap ball

· Social Skills: encourage cooperative play

Approaches to Learning: small group engagement; children sustain attention independently with partner

Soccer

· Motor Movement: focus on accuracy and kicking ball into goal

· Accuracy: kicks ball aiming for goal

· Social Skills: encourage cooperative play; children share materials and take turns

· Approaches to Learning: small group engagement; children sustain attention independently with partner

Cool Down

· Motor Imitation touch toes, bend and stretch, ride the bike, hug knees, yoga moves, wave goodbye

· Lower Heart Rate (slow down breathing)

· Cool Down Muscles

Unit 7 Example

 

Unit 7 Example notes

Time

Description

00:00-01:04

Unit 7: Warm-Up

Marching

Notice how teacher

· Has children move in a continuous circle

· Prompts child to move his arms

· Encourages children to join in the song

01:05-01:35

Unit 7: Warm-Up

Jogging

Notice how teacher

· Leads children in movement

· Has children stay on floor marker

· Prompts singing and movement by modeling expected behavior

· Visually monitors children during movement

01:36-02:32

Unit 7: Warm-Up

Lunging

Notice how teacher

· Leads children in movement

· Has children stay on floor marker

· Prompts movement by modeling expected behavior

· Visually monitors children during movement

02:33-03:32

Unit 7: Warm-Up

Kicking

Notice how teacher

· Leads children in movement

· Has children stay on floor marker

· Prompts singing and movement by modeling expected behavior

· Visually monitors children during movement

03:33-05:10

Unit 7: Warm-Up

Kicking

Notice how teacher

· Supports language skills by asking children what movement starts with a K and encouraging a child to use words to describe his movement (kicking)

· Provides model and prompts

· Alternates between low and high kicks

· Provides descriptive feedback for good balance

05:11-07:41

Unit 7: Warm-Up

Notice how teacher

· Provides child choice

· Distributes adults among children

· Leads warm-up with different movements (twisting, jumping jacks, rolling arms, lunging), emphasizing new vocabulary

· Provides reminders about lunging

07:42-08:25

Unit 7: Core Activity 1

We Tap the Ball

Notice how teacher

· Provides different size balls according to ability level

· Provides clear, step-by-step instructions, lowering her voice to highlight soft tapping

· Models movement and even demonstrates non-example (tapping ball hard)

· Has children practice a soft tap with their hand while describing the difference between tapping and stomping

08:25-10:11

Unit 7: Core Activity 1

We Tap the Ball

Notice how teacher

· Supports school readiness skills during the transition by asking children to listen for their turn to get a ball (girls then boys)

· Lets children choose a ball to use

· Provides models with verbal prompts

· Employs another adult to provide individual support for a child

· Begins the activity with one foot and then progresses to alternating feet

· Provides praise for singing and movements

10:12-12:32

Unit 7: Core Activity 1

We Tap the Ball

Notice how

· Teacher provides model and goes at a slow pace

· Teacher asks children to help sing

· Some children hold hands to help one another balance

· Teacher alternates between tapping the ball with toes and heels

12:33-14:25

Unit 7: Core Activity 1

We Tap the Ball

Notice how

· Various size balls are provided (small, big)

· All staff are utilized to provide support

· Teacher utilizes prompts (It’s like walking a dog, Trap the ball between your feet)

· Teacher walks around to support children rather than kicking the ball alongside them

14:26-15:20

Unit 7: Core Activity 2

Roll & Kick

Notice how

· Children are in partners whereas Soccer and Roll and Kick occur simultaneously

· Teacher begins the activity with a review of instructions and clearly explains the objective is to control the ball

· Children are in pairs and each child is standing on a floor marker

· Teacher stands close to one pair and supports them with prompts and modeling

· One child gently taps the ball to roll it to partner while the partner stops the ball with one foot

15:21-17:58

Unit 7: Core Activity 2

Roll & Kick

Notice how teacher

· Places children in pairs

· Adjusts the distance between pairs to account for level of difficulty as well as ensure all children are engaging in balance rather than leaning against the wall while kicking.

· Monitors all pairs of children

· Offers 1-1 support as needed (holds hands with child)

· Provides words of encouragement (do you guys play soccer?)

17:59-19:31

Unit 7: Core Activity 3

Soccer

Notice how

· Teacher offers 1-1 support (holds child’s hands, prompts)

· Partner shakes goal to ring bell when a goal is scored

· Supports school readiness skills by encouraging 3 goals and then switching

· Supports social skills by asking child to help her partner (retrieve ball, move goal)

· Adjusts distance to simplify the activity for a child who is experiencing difficulty

19:32-20:39

Unit 7: Music Video

Hockey Pokey

Notice how the teacher

· Prior to starting the video the teacher reinforces personal space with children finding their own space by spreading their arms wide to ensure they are not too close to a friend

· Models each movement as well as provides additional prompts (lift it high)

· Provides encouragement (wiggle it!)

20:40-23:09

Unit 7: Music Video

Hockey Pokey

Notice how

· Teacher offers words of encouragement and models each movement

· Children sing along to music video

· Children are free to express language (not restricted to a small voice)

23:10-24:19

Unit 7: Cool Down

Bend & Stretch Touch Toes

Notice how the teacher

· Begins the activity with an explanation of why we do a warm-up and cool down

· Model movement

· Does not restrict where children sit on the carpet

24:20-25:40

Unit 7: Cool Down

Ride the Bike

Notice how the teacher

· Slowly transitions into the movement by breaking it down into steps (lie back carefully, then lift 1 leg in the air, then lift the other leg in the air)

· Adds voice effects rather than singing

· Easily transitions to hugging knees at the end of the movement

· Supports language skills with a discussion on stretching

Unit 7 Essential

 

Unit 7 Essential notes

00:00-01:26

Lesson Extension: Warm-Up

Wake Up Bodies

Notice how the teacher

· Extend warm-up buy beginning with a morning stretch

· Incorporate positional words and body awareness by stretching different body parts (toes, torso, arms, middle, side to side)

· Support language skills (say “good morning toes,”what do you feel stretching)

01:27-02:08

Lesson Extension

Cool Down

Notice how the teacher

· Extends cool down by incorporating the transition from music video into the cool down activities

· Children stay standing and stretch up tall and then touch toes

Teacher gradually progresses to a seated position

02:09-03:07

Lesson Extension

Cool Down

Notice how the teacher

· Extends cool down to include quiet time at the end of cool down

· Supports approaches to learning and language skills by asking children to listen for the letter of their first name before lining up

03:08-03:25

School Readiness: Language

Letters

Notice how the teacher

· Supports language skills during transition time

· Children use active listening skills to listen for their letter

· Children identify the first letter of their name

03:26-04:23

School Readiness: Math

Number Recognition

Notice how the teacher

· Children identify the number they are standing on

· Children use active listening skills to listen for their number and go retrieve a ball

· Teacher assists children and ensures all children know their number

04:24-04:44

School Readiness: Social

Help/Support Peers

Notice how the teacher

· Teacher encourages children to help each other (I like how friends are helping each other and holding hands)

· Children hold hands as they tap the ball

04:45-06:15

School Readiness: Social

Cooperative Play

Notice how the teacher

· Children are in pairs for soccer. One child kicks the ball while the other child helps support the goal.

· Teacher encourages child to help his partner score a goal

· Teacher encourages child to ring the bells when his partner scores a goal

· Employs UDL strategy by providing prompts to assist child kicking the ball (you can pick it up) and uses hand gestures to signal picking up the ball

06:16-06:40

School Readiness: Social

Cooperative Play

Notice how the teacher

· Children are paired for soccer. Children share equipment and support one another by holding the goal as the ball is kicked

· Children switch roles so both children get a turn kicking

06:41-07:50

UDL: Means of Representation

Multiple Communication Forms

Notice how the teacher

· Teacher employs UDL strategy with an auditory signal (ring bell) for transition time

· Teacher offers supports to a pair of children to help guide them to their place; Prompts adult to come be with one child who will need extra support

· Teacher asks children to hold hands with their partner as they transition to the next activity

07:51-08:13

UDL: Means of Engagement

Sustain Interest/Attention

Notice how the teacher

· Children have the option to use different size balls in order to either simplify the activity or create a challenge

· Teacher encourages child to use a smaller ball to simplify the activity

· Some balls are slightly deflated to prevent them from rolling away

08:14-09:16

UDL: Means of Engagement

Sustain Interest/Attention

Notice how the teacher

· Engages child by telling her to swap balls for a smaller ball. This simplifies the activity for the child.

· Encourages children to hold hands to support one another.

· Adds a challenge by asking children to alternate feet. However, some children do only use one foot to tap the ball as an alternate way of completing the activity.

09:17-09:50

UDL: Means of Engagement

Organize for Engagement

Notice how the teacher

· Engage children by employing various group sizes (partner activity)

· Alter support for children by walking alongside them to guide them to their place

· Support social skills by pairing children to encourage cooperative play

09:51-11:00

UDL: Means of Engagement

Organize for Engagement

Notice how the teacher

· All staff are utilized. There is 1 designated staff member for most partners while the Lead Teacher circulates among all children.

· Encourages children with praise (You’re all going to be part of the Revolution, the soccer team)

· Provides prompts as needed (David you can use your hands)

Class is placed into small groups and participate in different activities

11:01-11:48

UDL: Means of Engagement

Organize for Engagement

Notice how the teacher

· Vary level of support by providing 1-1 support to a child and his partner

· Offer a hand to help balance while kicking

· Provide prompts for encouragement and reminders (you can move your body, go get it)

· Teacher continually monitors other children as she provides 1-1 support
